title: Example Enterprise Set up
intro: To help understand how the basic concepts for setting up an enterprise come together, we will run through setting up an example enterprise.

blocks.content: The first thing after upgrading to an Enterprise account is to set up the Hierarchy structure that best suits your business / collaboration needs.

blocks.caption: From the root of the enterprise we are going to set up a few empty Groups to simulate departments of my Enterprise. Clicking on the 'Add' button in the header of the Hierarchy window gives you the available options.
Here we have added a new Group inside another group, effectively nesting it. In this case we have used it to denote a separate team inside a larger department.

Changing an entities name (Group or Template DB) can be done in the panel on the right hand side of the screen. You can change the name & icon of Groups and name & availability (public / private) of Template DB's.

blocks.content: Before adding your first members to your newly created structure, we will need to review and define roles with security rules to assign to our members.

blocks.caption: Selecting the 'Security' tab in the top bar will allow you to navigate to the Security Manager.
All Enterprises are created with default roles which can be edited to suit your needs. Refer to our dedicated guide on the Security Manager to help you set up the correct rules for your roles

blocks.content: A key feature in working with Enterprise is defining repositories of Templates for your departments and enterprise to use that are filled with Approved templates created using Lifecycles.

blocks.caption: Template repositories allow you to control the availability of Templates to the members of your Hierarchy, otherwise known as the data scope. Here we have created a structure to give a specific team its own repository along with a Lifecycle that can be used to collaboratively create Templates for internal use within the team.

Once the Lifecycle has been added to the hierarchy it is important to customise it to you needs, specifically selecting which stages are needed, names of stages, action labels & roles that are to be linked to each stage. (As defined in the previous steps).
